Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: You scared me to death, you mangy thing!

Speaker: wybie
Dialogue: Hoo! Let me guess, you're from Texas or Utah; someplace dried out and barren, right? I heard about water-witching before but it doesn't make sense; I mean, it's just an ordinary branch.

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: And I DON'T LIKE BEING STALKED, not by  PSYCHO-NERDS OR THEIR CATS!

Speaker: wybie
Dialogue: He's not really my cat; he's kinda feral you know, wild? Of course, I do feed him every night and sometimes he'll come in my window `n bring me little dead things.

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: MICHIGAN? And if I'm a "water witch",  THEN--  --where's the secret WELL?

Speaker: wybie
Dialogue: You stomp too hard and you'll fall in it!

Speaker: wybie
Dialogue: Surprised she let you move in...

Speaker: wybie
Dialogue: Uh... I'm not supposed to talk about it.

Speaker: wybie
Dialogue: Short for Wyborne. Not my idea, of course. What'd you get saddled with?

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: I wasn't saddled with anything. It's Coraline.

Speaker: wybie
Dialogue: Hmmm... It's not real scientific, but I heard an ordinary name, like Caroline --

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: I think I heard someone calling you, Wyborne.

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: Oh, I definitely heard someone, Why-were- you-born.

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: I almost fell down a well yesterday, Mom.

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: Hmmm. So can I go out? I think it's perfect weather for gardening.

Speaker: mel
Dialogue: No, Coraline. Rain makes mud. Mud makes a mess.

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: But Mom, I want stuff growing when my friends come to visit. Isn't that why we moved here?

Speaker: mel
Dialogue: Something like that. But then we had the accident.

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: Wasn't my fault you hit that truck.

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: I can't believe it -- you and Dad get paid to write about plants and you hate dirt.

Speaker: mel
Dialogue: Coraline, I don't have time for you right now. And you still have unpacking to do. Lots of unpacking.

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: Huh... a little me? That's weird.

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: Wybie. And I'm way too old for dolls.

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: Hey Dad, how's the writing going?... Dad?

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: D'you know where the garden tools are?

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: It's pouring out there, isn't it.

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: "Don't even think about going out, Coraline Jones."

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Then you won't need the tools.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: No, no, no, no, no; GAAAA--!

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: One boring blue boy in a painfully boring painting ... four incredibly boring windows ... and no... more... doors...

Speaker: mel
Dialogue: Will you stop pestering me if I do this for you?

Speaker: mel
Dialogue: They must have closed this off when they divided up the house.

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: You're kidding? And why is the door so small?

Speaker: mel
Dialogue: We made a deal. ZIP IT!

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: I think you are so nice, I give you bowls of porridge And I give you bowls of ice --

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: Why don't you ever cook, Mom?

Speaker: mel
Dialogue: Coraline, we've been through this before: your Dad cooks, I clean, and you stay out of the way.

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: Looks more like slime to me.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Well, it's slime or bedtime fusspot -- now what's it going to be?

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: Think they're trying to poison me?

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: Don't forget about me, guys. Okay?

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: Mom?! What are you doing here in the middle of the night?

Speaker: other mother
Dialogue: You're just in time for supper, dear!

Speaker: other father
Dialogue: Hello, Coraline. Want to hear my new song?

Speaker: other father
Dialogue: No need to ... this piano plays ME!

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: I, uh  sorry  but she said to tell you the food's ready.

Speaker: other father
Dialogue: Mmmmm! Who's starving? Raise your hand.

Speaker: other father
Dialogue: We give our thanks and ask to bless, Our Mother's golden chicken breast!

Speaker: other mother
Dialogue: Well, here comes the gravy train! Choo- choo!

Speaker: other mother
Dialogue: Another roll, sweet peas? Corn on the cob?

Speaker: other mother
Dialogue: We've been waiting for you, Coraline.

Speaker: other father
Dialogue: Yep. Wasn't the same here without you, kiddo.

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: I didn't know I had an Other Mother.

Speaker: other mother
Dialogue: Of course you do. Everyone does.

Speaker: other mother
Dialogue: Uh huh, and soon as you're through eating, I thought we'd play a game.

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: You mean like, hide and seek?

Speaker: other mother
Dialogue: Perfect! Hide and seek in the rain.

Speaker: other mother
Dialogue: Mud facials, mud baths, mud pies -- it's great for poison oak.

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: I think I should get to bed.

Speaker: other mother
Dialogue: Of course, sweetheart, it's all made up.

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: Kripes a-mighty, how are my best trolls? I can't wait till summer. You're both comin', right?

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: It's gone, my poison oak, it's gone!...

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: It was incredibly real, Mom! Only you weren't really you; you were my other mother.

Speaker: mel
Dialogue: Coraline, you only dreamed you ate all that chicken. Take your multi-vitamin, at least.

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: You were in the dream too, Dad. You had wild-looking pajamas and orange monkey slippers.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Orange? My monkey slippers are blue.

Speaker: mel
Dialogue: If the real Charlie Jones wants his pages edited, he'd better wrap them up ASAP.

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: Miss Spink and Forcible? But you said they're dingbats.

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: Circus?... Oh, uh, I brought this for you.

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: Oompah oompah, toodle toot, toodle toot.

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: The one behind the wall paper? But... it's all bricked up.

Speaker: miss spink
Dialogue: How nice to see you, Caroline. Would you like to come in? We're playing cards.

Speaker: miss forcible
Dialogue: April, I think you're being followed.

Speaker: miss spink
Dialogue: It's the new neighbor, Miriam - Caroline? She'll be having the Oolong tea.

Speaker: miss forcible
Dialogue: No, no, no, no. I'm sure she'd prefer Jasmine.

Speaker: miss forcible
Dialogue: Oh go on, have one  it's hand-pulled taffy from Brighton  best in the world.

Speaker: miss spink
Dialogue: Oh, your tea leaves, dear. They'll tell me your future. Drink up then, go on.

Speaker: miss forcible
Dialogue: Oh, give me that cup, April, your eyes are going.

Speaker: miss spink
Dialogue: My eyes! You're blind as a bat!

Speaker: miss forcible
Dialogue: Oh, now, ummm... not to worry, child, it's good news: there's a tall, handsome beast in your future.

Speaker: miss spink
Dialogue: Miriam, oh really, you're holding it wrong.

Speaker: miss spink
Dialogue: I see a very peculiar hand...

Speaker: miss spink
Dialogue: Giraffes don't just fall from the sky, Miriam.

Speaker: miss spink
Dialogue: Never wear green in your dressing room.

Speaker: miss forcible
Dialogue: Acquire a very tall step ladder.

Speaker: miss spink
Dialogue: And be very, very careful. Now, was there something you came to tell us?

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: No, I guess not. Thanks for the tea, though.

Speaker: wybie
Dialogue: Ow. I - I wasn't stalking you. We're hunting banana slugs.

Speaker: wybie
Dialogue: What? He hates to get his feet wet. Geez.

Speaker: wybie
Dialogue: Oh no; I found it that way. It's older than Gramma -- old as this house prob'ly.

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: C'mom - blue hair, my swampers and raincoat?

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: I meant my parents; they don't listen to me either.

Speaker: wybie
Dialogue: You know, I've never been inside the Pink Palace.

Speaker: wybie
Dialogue: Grandma would kill me. Thinks it's dangerous or something.

Speaker: wybie
Dialogue: Well... she had a twin sister.

Speaker: other mother
Dialogue: So thoughtful of you to send this nice cheddar, Coraline.

Speaker: other mother
Dialogue: Would you go fetch your father?

Speaker: other mother
Dialogue: Your better father, dear.   He's out in the garden.

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: Oh ah, stop! Stop tickling, ah!

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: Well, she says it's time for dinner ... breakfast ... food?

Speaker: other father
Dialogue: Hop on, kiddo, I want to show you something!

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: I can't believe you did this!

Speaker: other father
Dialogue: Mother said you'd like it! Boy she knows you like the back of her hand.

Speaker: other mother
Dialogue: Coraline, Mr. Bobinsky has invited you to come see the Jumping Mice perform after dinner.

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: Really. That know-it-all Wybie said it was all in Mr. B's head, I knew he was wrong.

Speaker: other father
Dialogue: Well, everything's right in this world, Kiddo.

Speaker: other mother
Dialogue: Your father and I will clean up while you and your friend head upstairs.

Speaker: other mother
Dialogue: I thought you'd like him more, if he spoke a little less.  So I fixed him.

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: So he can't talk at all?

Speaker: other mother
Dialogue: Now run along, you two, and have fun.

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: You're awful cheerful, considering you can't say anything.

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: We loved it, Mr. B. It was ... so ... so--

Speaker: mel
Dialogue: Don't fret, Charlie, they'll love the new catalog. At least, they'll love my chapters.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Well, I guess I'll see you around, you dizzy dreamer.

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: But Mom, the whole school's gonna wear boring gray clothes. No one will have these.

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: My other mother would get them.

Speaker: mel
Dialogue: Maybe she should buy all your clothes.

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: So what do you think's in the other apartment?

Speaker: mel
Dialogue: I don't know. Not a family of Jones imposters.

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: Then why'd you lock the door?

Speaker: mel
Dialogue: Oh, I found some rat crap and... I thought you'd feel ... safer.

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: They're jumping-mice, Mom! And the dreams aren't dangerous; they're the most fun I've had since we've moved here.

Speaker: mel
Dialogue: Had to give it a try.

Speaker: mel
Dialogue: How do you feel about a mustard-ketchup- salsa wrap for lunch?

Speaker: mel
Dialogue: Mmm... Had to go food shopping anyway. Dad's planning something special.

Speaker: mel
Dialogue: You wanna come along? You can pick out something you like.

Speaker: mel
Dialogue: Look, Coraline... if things go well today, I promise I'll make it up.

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: Hmmm... Wybie's got a cat like you at home. Not the quiet Wybie; the one that talks too much. You must be the Other Cat.

Speaker: cat
Dialogue: No. I'm not the other anything. I'm me.

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: Um... I can see you don't have button eyes. But if you're the same cat, how can you talk?

Speaker: cat
Dialogue: Well, you're clearly the expert on these things. After all, I'm just a big fat wuss puss.

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: Come back. Please? I... I'm sorry I called you that, I really am.

Speaker: cat
Dialogue: I've been coming here for a while.

Speaker: cat
Dialogue: Not like any "mother" I've ever known.

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: What do you mean? She's amazing!

Speaker: cat
Dialogue: You probably think this world is a dream come true. But you're wrong. The Other Wybie told me so.

Speaker: cat
Dialogue: Perhaps not to you. We cats, however, have far superior senses than humans and can see and smell, and --

Speaker: young forcible
Dialogue: What a piece of work is man! How noble in reason!

Speaker: young spink
Dialogue: How infinite in faculty! In form and moving how express and admirable!

Speaker: young spink
Dialogue: In apprehension how like a god!

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: Oh yeah. They swooped down and pulled me right out of my seat  Spink and Forcible. Only they weren't old ladies, that was just a disguise. But then, I was flying through the air and... it was, it was magic.

Speaker: other mother
Dialogue: You do like it here, don't you, Coraline?

Speaker: other mother
Dialogue: You could stay here forever... if you want to.

Speaker: other father
Dialogue: Sure...we'll sing and play games, and Mother will cook your favorite meals.

Speaker: other mother
Dialogue: There's one tiny little thing we need to do.

Speaker: other mother
Dialogue: Oh, but we need a yes ... if you want to stay here.

Speaker: other father
Dialogue: So sharp you won't feel a thi-- Oww!

Speaker: other mother
Dialogue: There now; it's your decision, darling. We only want what's best for you.

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: I'm... I'm going to bed! RIGHT NOW!

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: I'm really, really tired. Yeah...  I just need to sleep on things.

Speaker: other mother
Dialogue: Well of course you do, darling... I'll be happy to tuck you in.

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: Oh, no thanks, uh, you-you've done so much already--

Speaker: other mother
Dialogue: You're welcome. And I  Soon you'll see things our way.

Speaker: magic dragonfly
Dialogue: What's wrong, Coraline? Don't you want to play?

Speaker: toy squid
Dialogue: Yeah, I wanna hugga your face!

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: I'm going home tonight, robots - and I won't be back.

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: Go to sleep, go to sleep, go to sleep...

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: Go to sleep, go to sleep, go to sleep...

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: Hey you! Where's the Other Mother?     I want to go home.

Speaker: other father
Dialogue: All will be swell, soon as Mother's refreshed. Her strength is our strength.

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: If you won't even talk to me, I'm gonna find the Other Wybie. He'll help me.

Speaker: other father
Dialogue: No point; he pulled a long face...

Speaker: cat
Dialogue: And what do you think you're doing?

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: Well, I'm gettin' outta here. That's what I'M doing.

Speaker: cat
Dialogue: Nothing out here ... it's the empty part of this world. She only made what she knew would impress you.

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: But why? Why does she want me?

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: Eat? That's ridiculous, mothers don't eat daughters!

Speaker: cat
Dialogue: I don't know. How do you taste?

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: Huh? But how can you walk away from something and still come back to it?

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: Stop, he's one of the circus mice!

Speaker: cat
Dialogue: I don't like rats at the best of times, but this one was sounding an alarm.

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: I want to be with my real mom and dad. I want you to let me go.

Speaker: other mother
Dialogue: Is that any way to talk to your mother?

Speaker: other mother
Dialogue: I'll give you to the count of three. One...

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: You ... you mean the Other Mother? ...

Speaker: boy ghost
Dialogue: Don't remember our names... But I `member my true mommy...

Speaker: boy ghost
Dialogue: And saw that we weren't    happy.

Speaker: boy ghost
Dialogue: She said that she loved us,

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: Well, she can't keep me in the dark forever; not if she wants to win my life. Beating her is my only chance.

Speaker: boy ghost
Dialogue: Find our eyes, mistress, and our souls will be freed.

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: Come on. She'll hurt you again!

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: Anybody here? Hello, hello, hello! Real Dad ... Real Mom!

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: I missed you guys so much-- You'll never--

Speaker: wybie
Dialogue: Huh? Ha ha ha....yeah... Um, so you know tha-that old doll I gave you?

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: You stole that doll, didn't you?

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: It used to look like this pioneer girl; then Huck Finn junior; then it was this Little Rascals chick with all these ribbons, and braids, and....

Speaker: wybie
Dialogue: Uh, listen, I-I-I'm really not supposed  TO--

Speaker: wybie
Dialogue: C-can you  can you unlock it?

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: Not in a million years. But it wouldn't matter; she can't escape without her eyes. None of the ghosts can.

Speaker: wybie
Dialogue: Huhhhhhh... So, uh, I really need to get that doll?

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: Great! I'd love to get rid of it!

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: Where are you hiding, you little monster?!

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: The doll's her spy! It's how she watches you, finds out what's wrong with your life!

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: NO! - the Other Mother! She's got this whole world where everything's better - the food, the garden, the--  --neighbors.

Speaker: wybie
Dialogue: Yeah... Uh, I think I heard someone calling me, Jonesy.

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: Don't believe me?... You can ask the cat!

Speaker: wybie
Dialogue: The cat... I-I'll just tell Gramma that you couldn't find the doll-- OW!

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: Crazy?... You're the jerk-wad that gave me the doll!

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: Pick it up, Dad, pick it up.

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: Uh... don't you only make wings for the ... dead ones?

Speaker: miss spink
Dialogue: Just looking ahead dear... Angus hasn't been feeling very well of late.

Speaker: miss spink
Dialogue: We've lost our ride, Miriam. Caroline says her parents have vanished, quite completely.

Speaker: miss forcible
Dialogue: What?! We've waited months for those tickets.

Speaker: miss forcible
Dialogue: With your gamy legs? It's nearly two miles to the theater!

Speaker: miss spink
Dialogue: Oh, oh yes ... your missing parents. We know just what you need. Miriam, get...that's right.

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: How is hundred-year-old candy going to  HELP--

Speaker: miss spink
Dialogue: Well,it might help. They're good for bad things, sometimes.

Speaker: miss forcible
Dialogue: No, they're good for lost things.

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: Hello. How did you get in?

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: They're not coming back, are they  Mom and Dad. Not on their own.

Speaker: cat
Dialogue: You know, you're walking right into her trap.

Speaker: cat
Dialogue: Challenge her then. She may not play fair but she won't refuse. She's got a thing for games.

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: Coraline, you came back for us!

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: Darling!  Why would you run away from me?

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: They weren't bored of me.   You stole them!

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: Why don't you have your own key?

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: Mom, Dad, where'd she hide you?

Speaker: other mother
Dialogue: And what is it you'd be finding, Coraline?

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: And, and the eyes of the ghost children.

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: If I lose, I'll stay here with you forever and let you love me.  And I'll let you sew buttons into my eyes.

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: Then you let me go. You let everyone go my real father and mother, the dead children, everyone you've trapped here.

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: Not till you give me a clue.

Speaker: other father
Dialogue: Sorrry, so sorrry, Motherrr making meeee.

Speaker: boy ghost
Dialogue: Bless you, miss, you found me! But there's two eyes still lost.

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: Don't worry, I'm getting the hang of it!

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: You don't get it, do you?

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: Of course you don't understand. You're just a copy she made of the real Mr. B.

Speaker: cat
Dialogue: I think I mentioned that I don't like rats at the best of times.

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: I think you might have said something like that.

Speaker: cat
Dialogue: It looked like you needed this one, however.

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: No, I ... I brought a friend.

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: You, you have a very funny way of showing it.

Speaker: beldam
Dialogue: So?     Where are they - the ghost eyes?

Speaker: beldam
Dialogue: No, I suppose not. After all, you still need to find your old parents, don't you? Too bad you won't have this.

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: I already know where you've hidden them.

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: Mom! Dad! I missed you so much!

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: I didn't break it. It must've broke when you escaped.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Coraline, I asked you to count all the windows, not put your knee through them.

Speaker: mel
Dialogue: Well, get yourself cleaned up,   we're going out tonight.

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: You're talking about... your garden catalog?

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: But look at the snow on your clothes...?

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: I have no idea what you're talking about.

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: Mr. B's not drunk, Mom, he's just...eccentric.

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: Well, I'm glad it's finally over!

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: But how?   I locked the door!?

Speaker: boy ghost
Dialogue: Tain't all bad, miss. Thou art alive ... thou art still ... living...

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: I -- I've gotta hide this somewhere, s- somewhere she can never ...

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: Oh.... my twitchy witchy girl, I think you are so nice ...

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: ... I give you bowls of porridge And I give you bowls of ice cream.

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: ... But I never give you sandwiches With grease and worms and mung beans.

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: Why did you change your mind?

Speaker: wybie
Dialogue: W-well, Gramma showed me this picture, after I called you crazy?

Speaker: wybie
Dialogue: Oh, man...what am I going to tell her?

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: Just bring her by the house tomorrow.      We can tell her together.

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: You know, I'm glad you decided to stalk me.

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: Thanks for helping me, Miss Spink, Miss Forcible.

Speaker: miss spink
Dialogue: Oh, much better, dear... But he can't duck his wings forever!

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Oh, excu-say-moi, but that pizza was delicious.

Speaker: mel
Dialogue: You were right, Coraline. I really hate dirt, but the tulips look nice.

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: How are the meeshkas, Mr. B?

Speaker: coraline
Dialogue: I'm Coraline Jones -- I've got so much to tell you!
